CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection joined to merits and dismissed (non-exhaustion of domestic remedies);Remainder inadmissible;Violation of Art. 2 (procedural aspect);Violation of Art. 6-1;Violation of P1-1
JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Christos Rozakis;Dean Spielmann;Giorgio Malinverni;Khanlar Hajiyev;Sverre Erik Jebens
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in PERSON .

CARDINAL . At the material time the applicant and her husband lived in a CARDINAL - room apartment in a block of flats at CARDINAL LOC in the city of PERSON , GPE . The applicant submitted a housing warrant ( ордер ) confirming her right to live in the apartment . She did not submit any documents proving that she had a title to the flat .
CARDINAL . NORP In DATE a military operation was launched in the territory of GPE .

CARDINAL . According to the applicant , on DATE the block of flats at CARDINAL Prospekt Revolyutsii was hit by a missile fired by the NORP armed forces during an attack on ORG . The applicant ’s flat and all her belongings were destroyed . It does not appear that the applicant witnessed the destruction .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant , her husband and other residents were sheltering from a bombardment in the basement of their block of flats . At TIME an intoxicated man armed with a machine gun came down to the basement and started shooting , with the result that the applicant ’s husband and CARDINAL other persons were killed . The applicant managed to escape . According to her , the name of the man who shot her husband was PERSON . He had lived for some time in their block of flats and during the bombings she had met him in the basement on several previous occasions .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant buried her husband ’s body and the bodies of the others killed in the shooting in the courtyard . It does not appear that an autopsy was performed or any photographs taken .

CARDINAL . On DATE a local registry office certified the death of the applicant ’s husband . On the same date a housing authority issued the applicant with a certificate confirming that her flat “ was destroyed and burnt completely during the military actions on DATE ” . The certificate contained no other information relating to the destruction . The applicant did not submit any documents which would indicate the cause of the destruction of the block of flats at CARDINAL ORG , or any photographs of the site of the destruction .

CARDINAL . According to the Government , the applicant ’s written complaint concerning her husband ’s murder was received by ORG of the Interior of ORG on DATE . On DATE the acting prosecutor of ORG opened an investigation into the case under LAW ) ( aggravated murder ) of LAW . The case file was assigned the number DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was granted the status of victim of a crime and questioned . She reiterated her account of the events of DATE and described the appearance of the alleged murderer .

CARDINAL . In the ORG ’s submission , on DATE the investigation authorities also inspected the scene of the incident in the applicant ’s presence . The Government did not produce any report on that inspection .

CARDINAL . On DATE the proceedings in case no . DATE were suspended for failure to establish the identity of the alleged perpetrator . The applicant was informed in writing that the proceedings had been adjourned on CARDINAL [ rather than DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the criminal proceedings were reopened . According to the Government , on the same date , upon the applicant ’s request of CARDINAL DATE , the investigator in charge ordered the exhumation of the corpses of those killed on DATE , including the applicant ’s husband . The exhumation and forensic examination were carried out on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the investigation was stayed as it was impossible to establish those responsible . It does not appear that there was any investigative activity DATE and DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the decision of DATE was set aside and the proceedings in criminal case no . DATE were resumed , the applicant being notified in a letter of DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the investigation into the killing of the applicant ’s husband was again suspended in the absence of information concerning those responsible . It appears that the applicant was not informed of that decision until DATE , when the PERSON prosecutor ’s office stated in their letter that the criminal proceedings instituted on DATE in connection with the killing of the applicant ’s husband had been suspended on DATE for failure to find the alleged perpetrators , and that the search for those responsible was under way .

CARDINAL . In a letter of CARDINAL DATE ORG for ORG notified the applicant that the investigation in connection with her husband ’s murder had been commenced on CARDINAL [ rather than DATE , that the case had been given the number DATE and that the suspect in the case , PERSON . S. , had been an officer of ORG [ a security service established when the former President of GPE , PERSON , had been in power ] . The letter stated that the suspect was presently on the federal wanted list .
CARDINAL . It does not appear that any investigative activity took place DATE and DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the criminal proceedings in case no . DATE were re - opened . The applicant was informed of this decision on the same date .

CARDINAL . On DATE the investigating authorities stayed the criminal proceedings on account of their inability to establish the alleged perpetrator and apprised the applicant of their decision on the same date .
CARDINAL . It does not appear that any investigative activity took place DATE and DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the investigation was resumed . The investigating authorities informed the applicant of that decision in a letter of DATE . According to the ORG , the conduct of the investigation was being supervised by ORG .

CARDINAL . In the ORG ’s submission , apart from the applicant , the investigating authorities also questioned CARDINAL witnesses . CARDINAL of them , the applicant ’s neighbour who had helped her to bury the bodies , gave oral evidence similar to the applicant ’s account , whereas the others did not provide any relevant information . According to the Government , the investigating authorities also sent a number of queries to “ competent bodies ” . In particular , such queries were sent on DATE , DATE and DATE , DATE and CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . The Government also submitted that the investigation had obtained information that the murder of the applicant ’s husband and other victims had been committed by PERSON ( GPE ) PERSON , who had been an officer of a security service established when the former President of GPE , PERSON , had been in power . During the investigation , an address of PERSON ’s acquaintance had been established , but the house at that address had proved to be deserted . The investigators also verified the possible involvement of a number of persons with the surname “ PERSON ” in the killing of DATE , but that had brought no positive result .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant issued civil proceedings against a number of ORG before ORG of Stavropol ( “ the ORG ” ) . In her written submissions to the court the applicant sought damages in respect of her husband ’s death . She also stated that the block of flats in which she lived had been destroyed by a missile and asked the court to award her compensation for the destroyed flat and belongings that had been in the flat . As can be ascertained from a copy of her written submissions , the applicant enclosed copies of her passport , the marriage certificate , the death certificate , the housing warrant , a letter from a local authority , and certificates from the housing authority .
CARDINAL . By a default judgment of DATE ORG allowed in part the applicant ’s compensation claim for her husband ’s death and awarded her MONEY ( RUB ) .

CARDINAL . As regards the applicant ’s compensation claim concerning the destruction of her property , the court noted that under LAW of GPE the ORG was liable only for damages caused by its agents’ actions which were unlawful . It further found that the actions of the NORP federal troops in GPE had been lawful , as the military operation in GPE had been launched under Presidential Decree no . GPE of DATE and Governmental Decree no . CARDINAL of DATE , both of which had been found to be constitutional by ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . The court further stated that the applicant had submitted no evidence proving a causal link between the GPE actions and the damage sustained by her , since the military actions had been carried out by both parties to the conflict . Therefore the destruction of the applicant ’s possessions could not be imputed to the defendants .

CARDINAL . The court further held that under LAW of GPE damage inflicted by a “ source of increased danger ” ( источник повышенной опасности ) was to be compensated for by the person or entity using that source , unless it was proven that the damage had been caused by force majeure or through the fault of the affected person . However , in the court ’s view , the applicant ’s reference to the above Article was unfounded , as weapons and military equipment , in the circumstances of the present case , could not be regarded as a “ source of increased danger ” , since they had been used strictly for the purposes they were designed for and under the firm control of the relevant personnel . Moreover , the applicant had not adduced any evidence which would enable the court to establish the type and ownership of the weapon which had destroyed the applicant ’s housing .

CARDINAL . The court also noted that the applicant had submitted no documents confirming the value of her lost property . It noted in this respect that witness statements obtained during the hearing only enabled it to establish the existence of the possessions in the applicant ’s flat prior to the destruction and the fact that those possessions had been new . The court made no findings regarding the applicant ’s property rights in respect of the destroyed flat .

CARDINAL . The applicant ’s claims for compensation for non - pecuniary damage could not be granted either , in the absence of any fault or unlawful actions on the part of the defendants . In view of the above , the court concluded that there were no grounds for granting the first applicant ’s compensation claim for the destroyed property .

CARDINAL . It does not appear that the applicant ever sought the first - instance court ’s assistance in obtaining evidence relating to the weapon that had destroyed her housing . In her appeal against the judgment of DATE the applicant did not complain of her inability to obtain the evidence in question .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the first - instance judgment on appeal .
CARDINAL . On DATE , following the decision of ORG , the judgment of DATE became final and binding .
CARDINAL . According to the applicant , at some point ORG issued a writ of execution and sent it to ORG for execution on DATE .
CARDINAL . In the ORG ’s submission , the writ of execution was received by ORG on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG sent the applicant a letter inviting her to indicate the details of her bank account to enable the said Ministry to transfer the judgment debt to her .
CARDINAL . The applicant provided the necessary information on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the full amount due pursuant to the judgment of DATE was transferred to the applicant ’s bank account .

CARDINAL . In DATE , at the communication stage , the Government were invited to produce a copy of the investigation file of case no . DATE instituted in connection with the killing of the applicant ’s husband and other persons on DATE . Relying on the information obtained from ORG , the ORG refused to submit a copy of the entire file , stating that the disclosure of the documents would be in violation of LAW of LAW since the file contained personal data concerning the witnesses . They , however , produced a number of documents from the file , which can be summarised as follows .

CARDINAL . By decisions of CARDINAL DATE the ORG prosecutor ordered that criminal proceedings be instituted in connection with the killing of the applicant ’s husband and CARDINAL other persons by a man named PERSON using a machine gun on DATE and that an investigative group be organised for the investigation .
CARDINAL . By a decision of CARDINAL DATE the investigator in charge declared the applicant the victim of a crime .
CARDINAL . By a decision of DATE an investigator of the ORG prosecutor ’s office took up the case .

CARDINAL . By a decision of DATE the investigator in charge suspended the proceedings in case no . DATE . The decision stated that the term established for the preliminary investigation had expired , that all possible investigative actions had been carried out , but that it was impossible to establish the identity of the alleged perpetrator . The decision did not list the actions that had been taken during the investigation .

CARDINAL . In a letter of CARDINAL or CARDINAL [ the hand - written date is unclear ] DATE the applicant was informed that the investigation in case no . DATE had been stayed , as it was impossible to establish the identity of the person responsible .

DATE . On DATE the ORG prosecutor ordered that the investigation be resumed , citing “ the necessity of carrying out investigative actions ” . He did not indicate which particular actions should be taken . By a decision of the same date an investigator of the PERSON prosecutor ’s office took up the case .

CARDINAL . A decision of DATE of the first deputy prosecutor of ORG ordered that the investigation in criminal case no . DATE be resumed . It stated , in particular , that “ ... the investigation ... [ had been ] extremely superficial and was limited to carrying out several investigative actions and to including in the materials of the case file reports of investigating officers on the performed work and the results ” . It went on to say that the decision of DATE by which the investigation had been suspended for failure to establish the alleged perpetrator had been premature , before all investigative steps had been taken , and should be quashed . The decision of DATE further listed a number of investigative steps that should be taken during an additional investigation .

CARDINAL . In a letter of CARDINAL DATE the ORG prosecutor ’s office informed the applicant in reply to her query that the criminal proceedings had been suspended on DATE [ apparently a misprint , the correct date is DATE ] in the absence of any persons identifiable as the perpetrators . The letter went on to say that a study of the case file had shown the preliminary investigation into the circumstances of the death of the applicant ’s husband to have been superficial , and that the proceedings had therefore been resumed on DATE and the investigator in charge had been instructed to carry out an additional investigation .
CARDINAL . By decisions of DATE an investigator of the PERSON prosecutor ’s office took up case no . DATE and requested that DATE be fixed as the term of the preliminary investigation .

CARDINAL . On DATE the investigator in charge ordered that the proceedings be stayed , as “ during the additional investigation it [ had been ] impossible to establish those responsible ” . The decision did not specify whether any investigative steps had been taken , or if so , what they were .

CARDINAL . By a decision of DATE a deputy prosecutor of the LOC prosecutor ’s office set aside the decision of DATE and ordered that the investigation in case no . DATE be reopened . The decision stated that “ the investigation [ had been ] carried out superficially , haphazardly and unprofessionally ” and that “ the decision [ of DATE ] suspending the preliminary investigation [ had been ] premature and unfounded , without all the circumstances of the serious crime committed having been studied ” . The prosecutor thus ordered that the decision of DATE be set aside , given , in particular , the fact that the prosecutor ’s instructions of DATE had not been complied with . The decision did not list any particular investigative actions to be performed .
CARDINAL . On DATE an investigator of the LOC prosecutor ’s office took up the case , and on the same date informed the applicant of the reopening of the investigation .

CARDINAL . By a decision of CARDINAL DATE the investigator in charge stayed the investigation on account of the failure to establish the alleged perpetrator . The decision stated that during the additional investigation a query had been sent to ORG of GPE with a view to establishing the alleged perpetrator ’s whereabouts , and that , upon receipt of a reply to that query , a request was sent to the LOC prosecutor ’s office with a view to organising interviews with persons having personal details similar to those of the alleged perpetrator . The decision did not indicate whether any other steps had been taken . A letter of the same date informed the applicant of this decision .

CARDINAL . By a decision of DATE a deputy prosecutor of the PERSON district prosecutor ’s office ordered that the decision of CARDINAL DATE be set aside and the proceedings in case no . DATE reopened . The decision stated , in particular , that the decision to suspend the investigation had been unfounded and that the investigator in charge had failed to take all measures which could be taken in the absence of a person identifiable as a perpetrator . The decision further listed investigative measures that should be taken during an additional investigation . On DATE an investigator of the PERSON district prosecutor ’s office took up the case and informed the applicant of the reopening of the proceedings .
CARDINAL . A report on the exhumation dated DATE contains a detailed description of the site of the burial and the exhumed bodies .

CARDINAL . In DATE ( the date is unclear ) forensic medical experts drew up reports on the results of the examination . The report drawn up in respect of the body of the applicant ’s husband attested the presence of gunshot wounds to the head and neck .

CARDINAL . On DATE the investigator in charge sent a query to ORG in an attempt to find out whether any criminal proceedings had ever been brought against GPE ( ORG ) PERSON , aged DATE , who had been an officer of the security services established by rebel fighters , and if so , to obtain his full personal details and photographs , or in the absence of photographs to have people who might have known him questioned .

CARDINAL . During an interview of DATE the applicant re - stated the circumstances of the incident of DATE . She described in detail the appearance of PERSON , the man who , according to her , had shot her husband and CARDINAL other persons . She stated that he was of NORP origin and , since DATE , had shared a flat in their block of flats with another man of NORP origin , who had been their neighbour . Both of them had been armed with machine guns . She further stated that on TIME of the incident PERSON had come down to their basement in a drunken state and shot her husband and CARDINAL others with his machine gun . She had managed to hide in a dark corner of the basement . Immediately after the incident the applicant ran to a neighbouring block of flats where rebel fighters had been quartered and told them about the killing . According to her , they had taken PERSON out of the basement and started beating him with the butts of their machine guns and had promised her that they would commit him for trial . On DATE , with the assistance of her CARDINAL neighbours , the applicant had buried those killed near their block of flats . On DATE in the courtyard she had seen PERSON armed with a machine gun .

CARDINAL . One of the neighbours who had helped the applicant with the burial stated in her witness interview of DATE that she had learnt about the killing of the applicant ’s husband and CARDINAL others from the applicant . She gave oral evidence similar to that of the applicant and added that during the burial a man who had described himself as the former head of a security service established by rebel fighters had said that he knew PERSON and indicated the approximate vicinity of PERSON ’s residence .

CARDINAL . Transcripts of witness interviews held on DATE reveal that the investigating authorities questioned CARDINAL persons who were born in DATE , DATE and DATE and had the surname PERSON and the first names of PERSON or GPE . All of them stated that they had not been in PERSON during the period in question , did not know the man described by the applicant , and had no information regarding the incident of DATE .

CARDINAL . Transcripts of witness interviews on CARDINAL and DATE reveal that the investigating authorities questioned CARDINAL persons , apparently the applicant ’s neighbours . They all stated that they did not know , and had no information about , the man described by the investigators .

CARDINAL . The Government also adduced the transcript of a hearing held by ORG of Stavropol on DATE . According to this document , both the applicant and her legal counsel , PERSON , attended the hearing . It is clear from this document that both parties to the proceedings received explanations in respect of their rights and obligations , in particular , those established by LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . The transcript further reveals that the court heard both parties , the applicant having made statements similar to her written submissions to the court , and then CARDINAL witnesses , who described the belongings that had been in the applicant ’s flat prior to the destruction . The witnesses did not indicate the value of that property . As can be seen from the document , neither the applicant nor her representative had any questions , nor filed any motions . It is also clear that the court examined the following pieces of evidence : a copy of the marriage certificate , a copy of the passport , a housing warrant , a copy of the death certificate , an extract from a medical history card , CARDINAL certificates , CARDINAL letters , a copy of an identity document , parties’ written submissions , and summons .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of LAW of DATE in force at the relevant time provided that the competent authorities were under an obligation to take a decision in respect of any written or oral complaint concerning a criminal offence within DATE , or in exceptional cases DATE , from the date on which the complaint was received .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure of DATE in force at the relevant time stated that each party to proceedings must prove those circumstances to which it refers in support of its submissions . A court decides what circumstances are relevant for the case and which party must prove them and proposes those circumstances for discussion even if some of them have not been referred to by any of the parties . Evidence is submitted by the parties and other persons involved in the proceedings . A court may propose that the parties or other persons involved in the proceedings submit additional evidence . If it is complicated for the parties or other persons involved in the proceedings to submit additional evidence , the court , on their request , assists them in obtaining that evidence .

DATE . Section CARDINAL of the Law on Enforcement Proceedings of DATE provides that a bailiff ’s order on the institution of enforcement proceedings must fix a time - limit for the defendant ’s voluntary compliance with a writ of execution . The time - limit may not exceed DATE . The bailiff must also warn the defendant that coercive action will follow , should the defendant fail to comply with the time - limit .
CARDINAL . Under LAW , enforcement proceedings should be completed within DATE following receipt of the writ of enforcement by the bailiff .
